title: Synapsis and obligate recombination between the sex chromosomes of male laboratory mice carrying the Y* rearrangement

body_text.text: Abstract. The synaptic and recombinational behavior of the sex chromosomes in male laboratory mice carrying the Y* rear rangement was analyzed by light and electron microscopy. Examination of zygotene and pachytene X-Y* configurations revealed a surprising paucity of the staggered pairing configura tion predicted from the distal position of the X pseudoautosomal region and the subcentromeric position of the Y* pseudoautosomal region. When paired at pachynema, the X and Y* chro mosomes usually assumed configurations similar to those of typ ical sex bivalents from normal male laboratory mice. The X and Y* chromosomes were present as univalents in more than half of the early-and mid-pachytene nuclei, presumably as a result of steric difficulties associated with homologous alignment of the pseudoautosomal regions. When paired at diakinesis and meta phase 1. the X and Y* chromosomes exhibited an asymmetrical chiasmatic association indicative of recombination within the staggered synaptic configuration. Both pairing disruption and recombinational failure apparently contribute to diakinesis/metaphase I sex-chromosome univalency, as most cells at these stages possessed X and Y* univalents lacking evidence of prior recombination. Recombinant X or Y* chromosomes were de tected in all metaphase II complements examined, thus substan tiating the hypothesis that X-Y recombination is a prerequisite for the normal progression of male meiosis.

Since Roller and Darlington's (1934) observations of exten sive X-Y synapsis at prophase I in the Norway rat (Rattus norvegicus), the subject of homologous pairing and recombination between the mammalian X and Y chromosomes has been the focus of considerable interest and investigation among cytoge neticists. Over the last 15 years, electron-microscopic analyses of synaptonemal complex preparations have clearly demon strated X-Y pairing in the Norway rat (Joseph and Chandley. 1984) , the laboratory mouse (Moses. 1977a; Goetz et al.. 1984) , and a variety of other mammals (e.g.. Moses. 1977c; Schmid et al.. 1987 : Sudman and Greenbaum. 1990 . Light-microscopic observations of diakinesis and metaphase I configurations reveal a distinct interstitial chiasma between the X and Y chromosomes in some mammals, but these represent unique instances where homologous heterochromatic segments have been added to the original sex chromosomes (Schmid et al.. 1987; Haleetal.. 1991 . and references therein) or where translo-cated autosomal segments comprise a substantial portion of the sex bivalent (Wahrman et al., 1983; Tucker and Bickhant. 1986) . For the majority of mammalian species, a characteristic end-to-end association of the X and Y chromosomes is observed at diakinesis and metaphase I. This configuration has been regarded as a small terminalized chiasma (Ohno et al., 1959; Burgoyne, 1982 : Evans et al., 1982 or as an achiasmatic asso ciation that ensures proper segregation of the X and Y chromo somes at anaphase I (Ashley, 1984) . Inheritance and cvtological data from laboratory mice carrying the sex-reversed(Sxr) muta tion (Lyon et al.. 1981 : Evans et al., 1982 support the chias matic interpretation of X-Y association and suggest that only those cells in which the X and Y chromosomes have paired and recombined can successfully complete meiosis and contribute to the gametic pool.

In the previous paper (Eicher et al.. 1991) , we presented a cytogenetic and molecular analysis of the Y* rearrangement of the mouse Y chromosome. Chromosomal banding and in situ hybridization revealed that the Y* rearrangement involved the translocation of a functional centromere and associated major satellite sequences from an unknown chromosome to a position adjacent to the Y pseudoautosomal region. Consequently, the pseudoautosomal region, which is normally positioned at the distal (noncentromeric) end of the Y chromosome, occupies an interstitial position adjacent to the new' functional centromere of the Y* chromosome. Consequently, the pseudoautosomal region (horizontal lines) occupies an interstitial position adjacent to the new func tional centromere of the Y* chromosome. The morphology and m itotic stabil ity o f the Y* chromosome indicate that the normal Y centromere was either inactivated or deleted during the Y* rearrangement. In this paper, we present a light-and electron-microscopic analysis of the meiotic behavior of the X and Y* chromosomes in LT/SvEi-Y* mice. The primary objective of this investigation was to analyze the synaptic and chiasmatic associations of the X and Y* chromosomes at pachynema and diakinesis/metaphase I. Banded metaphase II configurations were also examined to determine the extent of X-Y* recombination, thereby testing the hypothesis that crossing-over between the sex chromosomes is necessary for the normal progression of male meiosis.

LT/SvEi and LT/SvEi-Y* male mice were utilized in this study. Since the Y* rearrangem ent occurred on an LT/SvEi inbred strain background (Eichcr et al., 1991) , LT/SvEi males represent the ideal controls for this analysis. For ease o f presentation and discussion. LT/SvEi and LT/SvEi-Y* individuals are hereafter denoted as XY and XY*. respectively.

Testicular material from four XY and four XY* males was prepared for electron microscopy by the surface-spreading procedure described by Moses (1977b) . These preparations were stained with silver nitrate (Howell and Black. 1980) , mounted on 100-mesh copper grids, and examined using a JF.OI. JEM -I00CX II transmission electron microscope at an accelerating voltage o f 60 kV. Zygotene and pachytene substaging (early, m id, late) of primary spermatocytes followed the criteria established for the laboratory mouse by Dresser et al. (1987) and Goetz el al. (1984) . The behavior of the sex-chromosome axes was observed in surface-spread nuclei from late zygo nema through diplonema. Pairing configurations were scored only from nuclei at early and mid pachynema, as these are the only stages at which the sex chromosomes are consistently paired in normal laboratory mice.

To obtain cells at diakinesis, metaphase I. and metaphase II. a portion of the testicular material from the four XY and four X Y* males was prepared for light microscopy as described by Hale et al. (1991) . Meiotic chromosomes from these individuals and an additional XY male were C-banded using a m odification of the technique of Sumner ( 1972) . Meiotic preparations from two additional X-Y* individuals were treated with the restriction enzyme I///I and stained with 4% G iem sa as described by Kaelblinget al. ( 1984) . Only primary spermatocytes in which both sex chromosomes could be unequivo cally identified were included in the light-microscopic analysis. Testis weights were determined in two age-matched groups of XY and XY* males. G roup I comprised 12 XY and 8 XY* individuals aged 6-8 wk. whereas G roup 2 included 14 XY and 7 XY* individuals aged 9-11 wk. Each testis was dissected free of the epididymis and adherent fat and weighed to the nearest milligram on a Mettler analytical balance.

The zygotene and pachytene behavior of the sex chromo somes in XY individuals was consistent with that previously described for normal male laboratory mice (Goetz et al.. 1984 : Dresser et al., 1987 . Pairing of the X and Y chromosomes was initiated at their distal (noncentromeric) ends during late zygo nema ( Fig. 2a ). Maximal parasynapsis (side-by-side pairing w'ith one set of aligned axial telomeres) was achieved by early pachynema, and in many nuclei the entire Y axis was paired with the X axis (Fig. 2b) . The centromeric heterochromatin of the X chromosome was often visible as a densely stained "cloud" surrounding the unpaired end of the X axis. Darkly stained material was not observed at the centromeric end of the Y axis. The length of the X-Y synaptonemal complex gradually decreased as pachynema progressed, with complete desynapsis of the X and Y axes occurring during late pachynema.

A total of 425 early-and mid-pachytene nuclei was scored from the control XY males ( Table I) . The X and Y chromo somes were present as univalents in 28 (6.6%) of these nuclei. The univalent X and Y axes were spatially associated in 19 (67.9%) of the 28 nuclei. The sex-chromosome univalents often formed autologously paired "hairpins" or "balloons" (cf. Speed. 1987: Tease and Cattanach, 1989) . The sex-chromosome axes were associated within the densely stained sex vesicle in all of the 116 late-pachytene and diplotene nuclei examined. a Includes four nuclei in which the X and Y* centromeres were paired, five nuclei in which the Y* centromere alone was within the paired segment, and one nucleus in which the X and Y* axes were paired at both ends.

The temporal sequence of sex-chromosome synapsis and desvnapsis in XY* males was not notably different from that observed in the XY control males. Although 12 late-zygotene nuclei were examined, the X and Y* chromosomes were at syn aptic initiation in only one nucleus. Pairing of the X and Y* axes commenced at one set of axial telomeres, but it was not apparent whether the proximal (centromeric) or distal ends of the X and Y* chromosomes were involved in the initiation event. Sexchromosome bivalents were present in 200 (44.1 %) of the 454 early-and mid-pachytene nuclei scored for the XY* males (Ta ble I). In 191 (95.5 %)ofthese nuclei, the X and Y* axes assumed a parasynaptic configuration similar to those observed in the XY males ( Fig. 2c-e ). During pachynema, the centromeric hetcrochromatin of both the X and Y* chromosomes was often dis cernible as darkly stained material enveloping one end of each axis. The centromeric heterochromatin of the X chromosome was the most consistently visible, and its position at the unpaired end of the X axis indicated that the Y* chromosome was paired with the distal segment of the X chromosome in the majority of parasynapsed X-Y* configurations (Fig. 2c ). The position of the centromeric heterochromatin revealed that the X and Y* centromeres were both situated within the parasynapsed segment in four nuclei ( Fig. 2d ), whereas the Y* centromere alone was within the pairing segment in five nuclei ( Fig. 2e ). The sex-chromosome axes were synapsed at both ends in one earlypachytene nucleus, but it was not apparent whether the X and Y* centromeres were aligned within the same pairing segment.

The staggered configuration predicted from the distal posi tion of the X pseudoautosomal region and the subcentromeric position of the Y* pseudoautosomal region was observed in 9 (4.5%) of the 200 early-and mid-pachytene nuclei with X-Y* bivalents. In seven of the nine nuclei, this synaptic association clearly involved overlapping of small segments of the X and Y* axes ( Fig. 2f-h) . The distance between the X and Y* axes was uniform and comparable to that separating the paired axes of normal X-Y bivalents. The other two nuclei possessed thick ened X and Y* axes associated in a "linear" fashion with little or no apparent overlapping region (Fig. 2i) ; comparable configura tions were not detected in early-and mid-pachytene nuclei from the XY controls. Only 9 (2.0%) of the 454 nuclei in the total sample possessed X-Y* bivalents with staggered pairing.

The X and Y* chromosomes were present as univalents in 254 (55.9%) of the 454 early-and mid-pachytene nuclei scored for the XY* males ( Table I) . The univalent axes were closely associated in 234 nuclei (92.1%). and the condensed centro meric heterochromatin of the X and Y* chromosomes was often coalesced into a single densely stained cloud (Fig. 2j ). Although the X and Y* univalents were clearly separated in 20 (7.9%) early-and mid-pachytene nuclei, their axes were associated within the sex vesicle in all 238 late-pachytene and diplotene nuclei examined. The axes of the univalent sex chromosomes often formed simple or complex hairpins and balloons (Fig. 2k, 1 ).

The long arms of the X and Y chromosomes were associated end-to-end in 313 (74.9%) of the 418 diakinesis/metaphase I cells scored from the XY individuals (Table 1) . The sex chromo somes were present as univalents in 25.1 % of the cells at these stages. In the C-banded meiotic preparations, the Y chromo some was uniformly darkly stained ( Fig. 3a) .

The X and Y* chromosomes were present as unival ents in 79.9% of the diakinesis/metaphase 1 cells (Table 1) . The respective sister chromatids of the univalent X and Y* chromo somes were of equal length, and C-and .d/i/I-banding revealed that darkly stained Y* material was not present on either chro matid of the X univalents (Fig. 3e) . Although the noncentromcric Y* chromatin usually stained darker than autosomal euchromatin in C-and /I/i/I-banded diakinesis/metaphase I spreads, the centromeric heterochromatin of this sex chromo some was differentiated in both bivalent and univalent configu rations. /1/i/I-banding frequently revealed the presence of a dis tal band on the long arm of the Y* chromatids (Fig. 3d,e ).

The sex-chromosome configurations present in 86 (90.5%) of the 95 metaphase 11 cells scored were consistent with the occurrence of a single crossover between X and Y* chromo somes paired in the staggered configuration. The striking mor phology and staining of the recombinant X and Y* chromo somes made them readily identifiable in the C-and /i/»l-banded metaphase II cells. The chromatids of the X chromosome were of unequal length, and the darkly stained chromatin of Y* origin was clearly visible on the recombinant X chromatid (Fig. 3f) -The recombinant Y* chromosome was also asymmetrical, as the noncentromeric chromatin of the recombinant Y* chromatid was not discernible (Fig. 3g) . The remaining nine (9.5%) meta phase II cells displayed X and Y* configurations that were apparently generated by abnormal pairing, recombination, and segregation. One cell possessed an X chromosome consisting of a single chromatid. Two metaphase II cells were aneuploid: one contained a single X chromatid and a darkly stained acentric fragment, while the other exhibited both X and Y* chromo somes consisting of single chromatids (Fig. 3h) . With the excep tion of the acentric fragment, the single chromatids in these three cells were nonrecombinant. Each of three pairs of sister metaphase II cells contained a large dicentric chromatid, a darkly stained acentric fragment, and nonrecombinant X and Y* chromatids (Fig. 3i) . The dicentric chromatid comprised an X chromatid with a Y* centromere at its distal terminus; in one cell this dicentric chromatid was separate, whereas in the other two cells it was attached to either an X or a Y* chromatid. Darkly stained chromatin was not apparent between the heterochromatic centromeres of the dicentric chromatid.

The mean testis weight of the XY and XY* individuals in Group 1 (aged 6-8 wk) was 81 ± 9 mg and 55 ± 4 mg. respec tively. In Group 2 (aged 9-11 wk). the average testis weight of XY and XY* individuals was 87 ± 13 and 61 ± 9 mg, respec tively. body_text.text: The X-Y* configurations present in prophase I. metaphase I. and metaphase II cells are consistent with the subcentromeric position and hypothesized inverted orientation of the Y* pseudoautosomal region (Eicher et al.. 1991: Fig. I) . The staggered configurations present in early-and mid-pachytene nuclei in volve a short segment of svnaptonemal complex reflecting homologous synapsis between the distally located X pseudoau tosomal region and the proximally positioned Y* pscudoautosomal region. The linear associations, which were unique to the XY* males, are apparently staggered configurations in which the short homosvnapsed region is obscured by one of the thick ened sex-chromosome axes. For X and Y* chromosomes associ ated in this staggered fashion, a single crossover between the aligned pseudoautosomal regions results in disproportionate exchange of chromatin located distal to the recombination site. Consequently, all X-Y* bivalents in diakinesis/metaphase I cells exhibit a distinct asymmetrical chiasma, which is indicative of unequal exchange between X and Y chromosomes (Sud man and Greenbaum, 1990) . In normal laboratory mice, the near-termi nal X-Y chiasma cannot be resolved by light microscopy because the amount of chromatin involved in homologous exchange is very small (Evans et al.. 1982) . Similarly, one lateral arm of the X-Y* chiasma is not cytologically detectable due to the small quantity of pseudoautosomal chromatin transferred from the normal X chromosome to the Y* chromosome. In con trast, the amount of chromatin transferred from the Y* chromo some to the X chromosome is comparatively large, and. conse quently, the X-Y* bivalent exhibits a unique L-shapcd configu ration at diakinesis/metaphase I. The occasional displacement of the centromere of the recombinant Y* chromatid suggests that the smaller side of the asymmetrical chiasma can terminalize completely, thereby releasing the cohesion between the non recombinant X chromatid and the recombinant Y* chromatid. The asymmetrical morphology of the recombinant sex chromo somes in metaphase II cells confirms the regular occurrence of unequal exchange between X and Y* chromosomes paired in a staggered fashion.

The very low frequency of staggered pairing configurations in pachytene nuclei is surprising, as the presence of chiasmatic X-Y* bivalents in 20% of the diakinesis/metaphase I cells indi cates that homologous alignment of the X and Y* chromosomes is occurring at a substantially higher frequency. This discrep ancy between the frequencies of expected configurations in pachytene and post-pachytene cells could have several causes:

1. Synaptic adjustment of the axial length inequality distal to the aligned X and Y* pseudoautosomal regions could result in parasynapsed sex bivalents in which the X and Y* long-arm tel omeres are aligned. The differential region of the X axis, which normally remains unpaired, would not be affected by this pro cess (Sudman and Greenbaum, 1990) . However, synaptic ad justment is apparently not occurring in the XY* males, since pachytene analysis failed to reveal the intermediate synaptic configurations expected during adjustment of such a consider able length difference. Furthermore, the axial length changes that would accompany synaptic adjustment of length inequali ties (Solari. 1977 1986; Sudman and Greenbaum, 1990) were not observed in early-pachytene nuclei from XY* individuals. 2. The staggered pairing configuration may be susceptible to artifactual disruption by the physical stresses (flattening and spreading) of the surface-spreading procedure, thereby causing the X and Y* axes to misleadingly present as associated unival ents. The predicted staggered configuration of the X-Y* bival ent is presumably more delicate than parasynapsed sex-chromo some associations, since it involves long segments of unpaired axes extending in a radial fashion from the relatively small region of homologous synapsis.

3. Pre-diplotene loss of nuclei in which X-Y* recombination had not occurred may contribute to the apparent "enrichment" (from 2.0% to 20.1%) of cells in which the pseudoautosomal regions had aligned and recombined during pachynema. The observation of unassociated X and Y* univalents in nearly 8% of early-and mid-pachytene nuclei, while only associated X and Y* univalents are present in late-pachytene and diplotene nuclei, suggests that some univalent-containing cells are lost during pachynema. A comparable selection process is evidently operating in human males exhibiting complete X-Y pairing fail ure, as most of their spermatocytes do not progress beyond pachynema (Gabriel-Robez el al.. 1990) . Similarly, pachytene and metaphase I data from XO/XY/XYY mosaic mice suggest that the progressive loss of XYY spermatocytes during pachy nema is related to the presence of sex-chromosome univalents (Palmer et al., 1990) . 4. A small number of the chiasmatic associations may result from aberrant recombination within X-Y* bivalents in which the centromeric end of the Y* chromosome was parasynapsed with the distal end of the X chromosome (see below; Fig. 4) .

We favor the second and third possibilities as the most plau sible explanations for the substantial difference between the fre quencies of expected configurations at pachynema and diakinesis/metaphase I.

Pachytene and diakinesis/metaphase 1 sex-chromosome uni valency comparable to that observed in X Y* males is also exhib ited by laboratory mice carrying the Sa t rearrangement of the Y chromosome (Chandley and Speed. 1987; Mahadevaiah et al., 1988; Tease and Cattanach, 1989) . The S a t rearrangement involves the duplication and transposition of all or part of the Y short arm. including the testis-determining region, to a position distal to the Y pseudoautosomal region (Evans et al., 1982; Singh and Jones, 1982 : McLaren et al.. 1988 : Roberts et al., 1988 . Tease and Cattanach ( 1989) attributed the synaptic fail ure associated with this rearrangement to structural heterozy gosity within pairing regions containing the Sa t segment on the X or Y chromosome. For the Y* chromosome, the amount of chromatin distal to the pseudoautosomal region is considerably greater than that distal to the pseudoautosomal regions of the XSxr or Y Sxr chromosomes. Thus, structural heterozygosity within the pairing region and resultant synaptic impairment could likewise account for the high incidence of sex-chromo some uni valency in X Y* males. Since the axial telomeres of the meiotic chromosomes are attached to the inner surface of the nuclear membrane (Moses. 1977a (Moses. , b: M oensetal., 1989 , there are apparently steric problems associated with homologous alignment and synaptic initiation at the X and Y* pseudoauto-diakincsis + pachynema metaphase I metaphase II Fig. 4 . Abnormal X-Y* pairing and generation of the dicentric and acen tric chromatids. The X and Y* pseudoautosomal regions (horizontal lines) are presumably aligned in an inverted fashion in the parasynapsed X-Y* bival ents. A single crossover between the pseudoautosomal regions produces a dicentric and an acentric chromatid, which are cylologically detectable at m etaphase II. Al diakinesis/metaphase I. the expected chiasm atic association is very sim ilar to that resulting from a single crossover between X and Y* pseudoautosomal regions synapseC in the expected staggered fashion . For diagramm atic purposes, the size o f the X and Y* pscudoautosornal regions is exaggerated in the pachytene configuration. somal regions. The proximal location and inverted orientation of the Y* pseudoautosomal region could result in frequent mis alignment with the distally positioned X pseudoautosomal region, thereby generating the observed asynaptic configura tions. An analogous pattern is seen in grasshoppers (Chloealtis compersa) in which the presence of a terminally positioned supenumerary segment displaces the normal distal region away from the nuclear membrane (Moens et al., 1989) . Pairing is nor mally initiated from the vicinity of the telomeres in this grass hopper. and. consequently, heterozygosity for this supernumer ary segment results in the misalignment and synaptic failure of homologous segments that are normally located at the distal end of the chromosome.

Autologously paired configurations similar to those ob served in the XY* males have also been reported for univalent sex chromosomes in XYV vr laboratory mice (Chandley and Speed. 1987; Mahadevaiah et al., 1988; Tease and Cattanach. 1989) . Chandley and Speed (1987) observed hairpin and bal loon Y chromosomes in XYivr mice and attributed the high fre quency of sex-chromosome univalency to the preferential estab lishment of homologous pairing between the normal testis determining region and the transposed Sxr region on the Ys'Tr chromosome. However, observations of structurally normal X and Y chromosomes assuming similar pachytene configurations (de Boer and Nijhoff, 1981: Speed, 1986; Mahadevaiah et al., 1988; Setterfieldetal.. 1988; Tease and Cattanach. 1989; Tease, 1990) indicate that autologous synapsis is characteristic of uni valent chromosomes, rather than being suggestive of homolo gous pairing between duplicated and rearranged chromosomal segments. Similarly, our data indicate that autologous pairing is not unique to Y* univalents, as it occurs within sex-chromo some univalents from normal XY males and within X unival ents from XY* males. We conclude that hairpin and balloon configurations are the consequence, rather than the cause, of sex-chromosome univalency in XY* individuals.

The variable incidence of X-Y univalency in diakinesis/me taphase I spreads from normal male mice is primarily attrib uted to two factors. Rapp et al. (1977) observed pachytene and diplotene X-Y univalencv in (C57BL/6 x DBA)F| males and hypothesized that the univalents in diakinesis/metaphase I cells are the consequence of X-Y pairing failure at zygonema and pachynema. Reports of increased diakinesis/metaphase 1 X-Y univalency concomitant with increased pachytene X-Y unival ency in laboratory mice (de Boer and Nijhoff, 1981: Chandley and Speed, 1987; Tease and Cattanach, 1989) and humans (Speed and Chandley, 1990 ) substantiate this hypothesis. Alter natively, other investigators contend that diakinesis/metaphase I univalency is a result of precocious dissociation of X and Y chromosomes that were svnapsed during pachynema (Imai et al.. 1981 : Matsuda et al.. 1982 . Our observations from XY* individuals indicate that both pairing failure and premature separation account for the sex-chromosome univalency at dia kinesis/metaphase 1. Presumably, a large proportion of diakine sis/metaphase I cells with univalent sex chromosomes is de rived from pachytene nuclei with X and Y* univalents. How ever, the substantially higher frequency of X and Y* univalents at diakinesis/metaphase 1 indicates that premature dissociation also occurs at levels comparable to or exceeding those observed in the XY controls. Without exception, the univalent X and Y* chromosomes present in diakinesis/metaphase I cells showed no evidence of prior recombination. These observations impli cate recombinational failure as the underlying cause for preco cious sex-chromosome dissociation in XY* males. Presumably, recombination is blocked by asynapsis or nonhomologous pair ing of the X and Y* pseudoautosomal regions in the majority of X-Y* bivalents. It is not clear whether recombinational failure is also responsible for diakinesis/metaphase I X-Y univalency in normal male laboratory mice. The displacement of the recombinant Y* chromatid and its centromere in some chias matic X-Y* bivalents (see. for example, Fig. 3c ) suggests that terminalization of the small pseudoautosomal chiasma could prematurely release the X-Y association in normal male labora tory mice.

Recombination within the aligned pseudoautosomal regions in the staggered pairing configuration resulted in the exchange of highly unequal amounts of chromatin between the X and Y* chromosomes. This generated pronounced chromatid asymme try in the recombinant sex chromosomes at metaphase II, thereby providing definitive cytological markers for assessing the extent of prior X-Y* recombination. The segregation data from the XY* males and the cytological composition of the XY* and Y*x chromosomes in the recombinant progeny indicate that virtually all functional spermatozoa are derived from sper matocytes in which this type of X-Y* recombination occurred (Eicher et al., 1991) .

Dicentric and single chromatids comparable to those ob served in the XY* individuals have also been detected in meta phase II cells from X-VvrY males (Cattanach et al.. 1990) . The composition of the dicentric chromatids in XSv' Y individuals indicated that the recombination event occurred within the dis tal region of both sex chromosomes, and thus Cattanach et al. (1990) attributed the dicentric chromatids to either crossover error between parasynapsed pseudoautosomal regions or re combination between pseudoautosomal regions that were paired in an inverted fashion. The data from XY* males are consistent with inverted pairing and recombination, as the composition of the dicentric chromatids observed in three metaphase II pairs suggests that recombination occurs within X-Y* bivalents in which the centromeric end of the Y* chromo some is parasynapsed with the distal end of the X chromosome (Fig. 4) . This pairing configuration may actually enhance the frequency of recombination between X and Y* pseudoautoso mal regions aligned in an inverted fashion: while the products of this type of recombination were observed in nearly 10% of metaphase II spreads from XY* males, less than 3% (4 of 138) of the metaphase II spreads from XY males contained dicentric and single sex chromatids. This aberrant X-Y* recombination could not be detected at diakinesis/metaphase I. as the pre dicted chiasmatic association is indistinguishable from that produced by recombination within the staggered pairing con figuration. First-division segregation of the sex chromosomes recombined in this fashion was unusual, as the presence of sin gle X and Y* chromatids in metaphase II spreads indicates that sister centromeres often underwent equational division at ana phase I. Additionally, the dicentric chromatids apparently re mained intact through metaphase II. despite the potential for breakage during the first mciotic division. While the ultimate contribution of these cells to the gametic pool could not be assessed, the recovery of XO offspring from XY* males (Eicher et al.. 1991) suggests that hypohaploid sperm are occasionally generated from spermatocytes in which abnormal X-Y* recom bination occurred.

Although the overall fertility of XY and XY* individuals appears to be similar, the mean testis weight of the XY* males was significantly reduced relative to that of age-matched XY males. Reduced testis weight is also characteristic of X Y Sxr males (Lyon et al., 1981) and is coincident with elevated sexchromosome univalency at pachynema and diakinesis/meta phase I (Chandley and Speed, 1987 : Tease and Cattanach. 1989 . As in XY* males, metaphase II cells from 5.\r-carrying males are derived from primary sper matocytes in which sex-chromosome recombination has oc curred (Evans et al., 1982; Cattanach et al.. 1990 ). The reduced testis weights associated with the Y* and Sxr mutations appar ently reflect the loss of spermatocytes with nonrecombinant sex chromosomes prior to the first meiotic division. In XYSïr males, there is a concomitant reduction in sperm count (Mahadevaiah et al.. 1988) . and in some cases these individuals show oligosper mia and sterility (Lyon et al., 1981) . The fertility of X Y* males is apparently unaffected by the attrition of primary spermato cytes, as these individuals produce normal-sized litters.

While some investigators contend that sex-chromosome pairing alone is sufficient to ensure spermatocyte survival (Miklos, 1974: Burgoyne and Baker. 1984) , the meiotic data from the X Y* males demonstrate that only those spermatocytes in which the sex chromosomes have paired and recombined will com plete meiosis and give rise to mature functional spermatozoa. All of the metaphase II cells examined were derived from pri mary spermatocytes in which X-Y* recombination had oc curred. Furthermore, the observed distribution of progeny from XY* males also indicates a single obligatory crossover between the X and Y* chromosomes (Eicher et al., 1991 ) . Together with the data from SAr-carrying individuals (Evans et al., 1982 : Cat-Downloaded by:

Access provided by the University of Michigan Library 35.7.39.109 -10/7/2021 3:20:17 PM tanach et al.. 1990). our results indicate that X-Y recombination is a prerequisite for the normal progression of meiosis in male laboratory mice. The physiological basis of the loss of primary spermatocytes with nonrecombinant sex chromosomes has yet to be elucidated.
